body: Did you train our model on CPU or GPU? You'd better debug the program step by step and see in which step the training is stuck.

It was done on CPU. I did find a correlation on the processing time v/s number of images in the training set. I have now reduced the training images to 2,500 - 2000 training + 500 val. 
Apart from this, conceptually, do you know why DBCNN maybe slow? 
I will check the training script once again. Until then, let this issue be open.
DBCNN has two branches, its computational complexity is relatively higher. It is highly recommended to train the model on GPU.
Unfortunately I couldn't get a GPU access until now. Can I train your model on Google Collab? Would you recommend that?
I think it's a good idea, although I am not familiar with the setup of training models on Google Collab.
Do you recommend me to keep the same learning rate?

I tried training your model on the LIVE dataset. Once 50 epochs are done, the training starts again?
Here is the console output
.............................................................................................

Prepare the network and data.
DataParallel(
  (module): DBCNN(
    (features1): Sequential(
      (0): Conv2d(3, 64, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), padding=(1, 1))
      (1): ReLU(inplace)
      (2): Conv2d(64, 64, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), padding=(1, 1))
      (3): ReLU(inplace)

      (6): ReLU(inplace)
      (7): Conv2d(128, 128, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), padding=(1, 1))

      (10): Conv2d(128, 256, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), padding=(1, 1))
      (11): ReLU(inplace)

      (13): ReLU(inplace)
      (14): Conv2d(256, 256, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), padding=(1, 1))
      (15): ReLU(inplace)
      (16): MaxPool2d(kernel_size=2, stride=2, padding=0, dilation=1, ceil_mode=False)
      (17): Conv2d(256, 512, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), padding=(1, 1))
      (18): ReLU(inplace)
      (19): Conv2d(512, 512, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), padding=(1, 1))
      (20): ReLU(inplace)
      (21): Conv2d(512, 512, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), padding=(1, 1))
      (22): ReLU(inplace)
      (23): MaxPool2d(kernel_size=2, stride=2, padding=0, dilation=1, ceil_mode=False)
      (24): Conv2d(512, 512, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), padding=(1, 1))
      (25): ReLU(inplace)
      (26): Conv2d(512, 512, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), padding=(1, 1))
      (27): ReLU(inplace)
      (28): Conv2d(512, 512, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), padding=(1, 1))
      (29): ReLU(inplace)
    )
    (features2): Sequential(
      (0): Conv2d(3, 48, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), padding=(1, 1))
      (1): BatchNorm2d(48, eps=1e-05, momentum=0.1, affine=True, track_running_stats=True)
      (2): ReLU(inplace)
      (3): Conv2d(48, 48, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(2, 2), padding=(1, 1))
      (4): BatchNorm2d(48, eps=1e-05, momentum=0.1, affine=True, track_running_stats=True)
      (5): ReLU(inplace)
      (6): Conv2d(48, 64, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), padding=(1, 1))
      (7): BatchNorm2d(64, eps=1e-05, momentum=0.1, affine=True, track_running_stats=True)
      (8): ReLU(inplace)
      (9): Conv2d(64, 64, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(2, 2), padding=(1, 1))
      (10): BatchNorm2d(64, eps=1e-05, momentum=0.1, affine=True, track_running_stats=True)
      (11): ReLU(inplace)
      (12): Conv2d(64, 64, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), padding=(1, 1))
      (13): BatchNorm2d(64, eps=1e-05, momentum=0.1, affine=True, track_running_stats=True)
      (14): ReLU(inplace)
      (15): Conv2d(64, 64, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(2, 2), padding=(1, 1))
      (16): BatchNorm2d(64, eps=1e-05, momentum=0.1, affine=True, track_running_stats=True)
      (17): ReLU(inplace)
      (18): Conv2d(64, 128, kernel_size=(3, 3), stride=(1, 1), padding=(1, 1))
      (19): BatchNorm2d(128, eps=1e-05, momentum=0.1, affine=True, track_running_stats=True)
      (20): ReLU(inplace)

      (22): BatchNorm2d(128, eps=1e-05, momentum=0.1, affine=True, track_running_stats=True)
      (23): ReLU(inplace)

      (25): BatchNorm2d(128, eps=1e-05, momentum=0.1, affine=True, track_running_stats=True)
      (26): ReLU(inplace)
    )
    (fc): Linear(in_features=65536, out_features=1, bias=True)
  )
)

If you only want to train a single time, you can modify the number of the random train/test split to 1

for i in range(0,10): ->  for i in range(0,1):

I trained the DBCNN model on my custom dataset and the best val srcc I could get is 0.2025, while training on the LIVE Dataset produced 0.8571. 
Here is a screen dump on the custom dataset. Do you recommend me to train for more epochs? I have set the learning rate at 1e-4, batch size is 32. Total number of images is 1500 (train+val)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/63153505/142736685-3bf99580-b2d3-4a68-8817-5c3585c6a490.png)
